contactForm.title: Also make to order
contactForm.text: When you enter into any new area of science you almost always find yourself.

about.title: MY STORY BEGAN EVEN MORE EARLY

chronology.value:
2009 old way

A dependent clause, also known as a “subordinate clause,” adds extra information to a sentence. It cannot, however, work as a sentence by itself. Example: Raghav dances only when Bhavya sings. Here, ‘Raghav dances’ is the independent clause and ‘only when Bhavya sings’ is the dependent clause. This is because the subordinate clause makes no sense on its own. It is “subordinate” because it “depends” on the main clause to make sense. This can further be clarified, by writing the two ‘sentences’ separately: Raghav dances. (correct and complete)
